fields.description:
If a group spans multiple directories, searching for a group by it's name returns a RemoteGroup object which corresponds to the first group found when cycling through the directories.

In particular, this does not amalgamate the members of a group spanning multiple directories (only members of the group in the first found directory are returned).
fields.summary: Searching for a group spanning multiple directories by its name will not amalgamate the principals

fields.description:
Confluence is currently using Atlassian User 0.X, once Confluence moves to 1.X we will have to change the current integration libraries for Crowd.

Bamboo is already using atlassian user 1.x so we will need to rename the atlassian-user-bamboo-integration to crowd-atlassian-user and crowd-atlassian-user to crowd-atlassian-user-legacy.

And from here update our docs for Bamboo and Confluence to reflect the versions supported by atlassian user pre and post 1.0

ie. Confuence 2.5.x and Bamboo 1.1.x  (and earlier) use crowd-atlassian-user-legacy, Confluence 2.6+ and Bamboo 1.2+ use crowd-atlassian-user
fields.summary: Move Crowd's current Atlassian User integration libraries to a 'legacy' module once Confluence starts using Atlassian User 1.3

{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 31 October 2013|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Hi everyone,
 
Thank you for your votes and comments on this improvement request. Whilst this is something we would like to implement some day, it is not at the forefront of our upcoming backlog.
 
We will be focussing on improving the integration of Crowd within our Atlassian suite of products, as well as simplifying and improving the overall user management and a unified administrative experience.
 
If our backlog changes and this improvement request becomes a priority, this ticket will be updated. If you'd like to better understand how we make roadmap decisions, have a read of : https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DEV/Implementation+of+New+Features+Policy
 
Cheers, Helen Hung
Atlassian Product Management

{panel}

Currently, a client application can "see" all the groups in the directories configured for that application.

Ideally, if {{Allow All To Authenticate}} on a directory is set to {{False}}, only the configured groups should be visible to the application. If {{Allow All To Authenticate}} on a directory is set to {{True}}, then the current behaviour of retrieving all groups is acceptable.
fields.summary: Client applications should only see groups which have been allocated to them

fields.description:
*Feature description*

The idea is to provide fail-over for a configured application in Crowd.

An application can have many directories connected to it, while this is usually used for applications that have multiple stores, a few Confluence customers have been asking for a failover option.

The idea is for Crowd to have multiple directory stores connected to an application that duplicate the Users and Groups in these directories. There will then be an attribute on the directory marking it as a failover directory, so if the primary directory fails with an IOException (for example) the second directory will be used, then the third, fourth etc, until success or utter failure.

*Possible workaround*

For problems with authenticating to an application in an event of a remote directory fail, it is possible to configure additional delegated authentication directories for each existing directory in Crowd pointing to a failover LDAP directory. While authenticating a user Crowd will automatically loop through configured directories. If authentication fails, Crowd will repeat the attempt with the next directory on the list.

However there are known problems with this approach which can be tracked here:
 * https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-4851
 * https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-4852

The workaround was tested with Crowd 2.10.1
fields.summary: Directory Failover option for an application

fields.description:
The libraries provided in the client directory are not enough.

See my comment from the documentation page http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/3.2.5+Integrating+Crowd+with+Cenqua+FishEye?focusedCommentId=62980132#comment-62980132

" At least I managed to get ride of the class not found problem.

The Crowd library in the library directory seems to be not enough. I have added the following to Fisheye:

    * commons-discovery-0.2.jar
    * commons-io-1.2.jar
    * commons-lang-2.3.jar
 
 And the configuration is accepted. I do not know which library was actually needed, however. "
fields.summary: Libraries in client directory are not enough

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 13 December 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

Thank you for taking the time to file and comment on this issue. Feedback like yours helps us release valuable Crowd features that solve problems for the greater customer base. To that end, we aim to keep our issues up-to-date so that they accurately reflect current customer needs. Because there has been no customer activity on this issue in a long time, we have marked it as closed. If you still feel that this issue is still relevant to your needs, please feel free to raise a new issue and link to this one.

If you would like to see how we select features for a new release, please read https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/Support/Implementation+of+New+Features+Policy.

Best regards,

Marek Radochonski
Senior Product Manager, Crowd
 [mradochonski@atlassian.com|mailto:mradochonski@atlassian.com]
 
{panel}


An error was found when importing data that only had \r for line endings
fields.summary: The CSV Importer needs to handle mulitple types of line endings (\r, \r\n etc.)

fields.description:
I set up a single tomcat to run Crowd and Confluence. Then I set up Confluence to authenticate in Crowd. Then I restarted the tomcat.

It happened that when tomcat starts, it tries to start Confluence context first. When Confluence context starts, it seems to be trying to authenticate in Crowd. But Crowd is not yet started, so Confluence initialization just hangs. All this is done in a single thread, so Crowd doesn't get a chance to start and the system hangs.

A workaround is to remove confluence context from tomcat, start normally, then add confluence context so it gets automatically deployed.
fields.summary: Tomcat doesn't start if it runs both Crowd and Confluence

fields.description:
It appears that {{jsessionid}} attributes are being added to all of the images/links/css/actions/forms in Crowd when running on Tomcat behind Apache.

When a browser first initiates a connection to Apache/Tomcat/Crowd the jsession attribute is there, however on a refresh the jsession is gone with the app server switching to a cookie mode. The {{jsessionid}} attribute is preventing actions from running on a form submission.

fields.description:
Currently it is possible to globally authenticate subversion DAV based repositories against Crowd using the Auth::Crowd module.  However if you wish to maintain more fine-grained group-based access (i.e. "members of group A have read-only access to sub-tree /foo/bar", etc) you need to maintain a separate file that duplicates the users and groups that are in Crowd (i.e. AuthzSVNAccessFile).  This is messy, duplicates work and is error-prone.

There are a couple of ways forward on this:
* Implement [CWD-391] and limit access within the Apache config via <location> blocks.
* Implement [CWD-204] and provide an example script that can generate the appropriate group mappings by querying the crowd server
* Duplicate mod_authz_svn functionality in the Auth::Crowd::Module
fields.summary: No group integraton into Subversion

fields.description:

     PerlAuthenHandler Apache::CrowdAuth

      PerlSetVar CrowdAppPassword XXXXX
      PerlSetVar CrowdSOAPURL http://foo/crowd/services/SecurityServer
      PerlSetVar CrowdValidGroups "web-access-group,sysadmin-group"

fields.description:
Provide meaningful names for xsd:elements in WSDL

Example of difficult-to-use schema
<xsd:element name="addPrincipalToGroup">
    <xsd:complexType>
        <xsd:sequence>
            <xsd:element maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1" name="in0" nillable="true" type="ns1:AuthenticatedToken"/>
            <xsd:element maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1" name="in1" nillable="true" type="xsd:string"/>
            <xsd:element maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1" name="in2" nillable="true" type="xsd:string"/>
        </xsd:sequence>
    </xsd:complexType>
</xsd:element>

Nice names produce better generated code and saves me a lot of brainpower
Which is group_name in1 or in2?  Which is user_name?  Did they change from 1.0.7 to 1.1.0? Is this the opposite of SecurityServer#addPrincipalToGroup? ...

Example of nice-to-use schema (from your wsdl)
<xsd:complexType name="PrincipalAuthenticationContext">
    <xsd:sequence>
        <xsd:element minOccurs="0" name="application" nillable="true" type="xsd:string"/>
        <xsd:element minOccurs="0" name="credential" nillable="true" type="ns1:PasswordCredential"/>
        <xsd:element minOccurs="0" name="name" nillable="true" type="xsd:string"/>
        <xsd:element minOccurs="0" name="validationFactors" nillable="true" type="ns1:ArrayOfValidationFactor"/>
    </xsd:sequence>
</xsd:complexType>
fields.summary: Provide meaningful names for schema in the WSDL

fields.description:
Crowd has stopped allowing crowd administrators to log in.  Previously, I was able to log in using both an account residing in the default hsql database and my own ActiveDirectory domain account.  The screen doesn't give an error, just refreshes to the login screen.  I'm attaching the log output.  alex-admin is the domain account, crowd is the hsql-kept account.  Crowd continues to respond correctly to requests from confluence and jira for authorization and authentication.  Nothing has changed in AD since the last time I logged in with the alex-admin account.

Right now, I need to turn back on the cache in Crowd, because confluence and jira are running very slowly, due, I believe from the profile, to crowd not having the cache on.  I turned off the cache the last time I rebuilt the crowd database (which I had to do because it wouldn't let me log in).  My most urgent question is: is there a way that I can enable the cache without going through the admin screens?  I have access to the hsql database files and the conf files.  Is there a way to modify these directly to turn on the cache?
fields.summary: Crowd is not allowing admins to log in.  Need to activate cache as quickly as possible

fields.description:
If the group that has been defined in the per-repository constraint does not exist, the access is granted to anyone (who is logged in). The default behaviour should be to deny access from everyone.

This might have some connection with CWD-217, as those kind of exceptions will be filed in the error log.

fields.summary: Tuckey rewrite filter dials home by doing a DNS lookup.

fields.description:
Bamboo will soon be supporting external databases (version 1.2). 

Once this occurs we will need to write an importer for Bamboo users and groups into Crowd. Since Bamboo is using Atlassian User, this should result in a very similar importer to the Confluence importer.
fields.summary: Create a Bamboo to Crowd Principal and Group importer.

fields.description:
Hi,
when trying to authenticate Confluence against LDAP, it demands a DN without spaces in the e.g. uniqemember attribute of the confluence-user group:

confluence-users: cn=confluence-users,dc=groups,dc=ops4j,dc=org
uniquemember: uid=test,dc=users,dc=ops4j,dc=org

However, when trying to see the members from Crowd, crowd demands spaces between the elements, something like
uniquemember: uid=test, dc=users, dc=ops4j, dc=org in order to show the user test as member of confluence-users

This leads to duplicated entries in order to satisfy both authentication methods. Not sure where the error is, maybe in different client libs used from Crowd 1.0.7 and Confluence 2.4.5 to LDAP?

/peter
fields.summary: Crowd and direct LDAP conenction demanding different DNs (at least against ApacheDS)

fields.description:
Updating a users credentials in ApacheDS is causing login attempts to fail.

The current assumption is that we are setting the password as clear text in ApacheDS when updating a Principals credentials when this should be set using the encryption configured for the given ApacheDS instance.

Link from forum: [http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257248348#257248348]
fields.summary: Updating a Principals credentials in Directory using ApacheDS causing authentication to fail.

fields.description:
{quote}
Email messages sent from Crowd don't have a sent date - I believe this is the RFC 822 "Date" header field - see SMTPMessage.setSentDate() in the JavaMail API docs. Unfortunately JavaMail doesn't default this field when it is not set, as qmail-inject does.

The result of the missing date is that user messages are often not seen because they are buried at the bottom of a mailbox that is sorted by date sent. 

Mail messages originating from Jira are sent on port 465 - these messages don't have this problem. In Crowd, we can't specify a port. I tried appending it to the name of the smtp server, but it didn't seem to work.
[ Show » ]
Nick Waanders - [23/May/07 08:31 PM ] Mail messages originating from Jira are sent on port 465 - these messages don't have this problem. In Crowd, we can't specify a port. I tried appending it to the name of the smtp server, but it didn't seem to work.
{quote}

fields.description:
We are a small software development company that uses Google Apps for our company office infrastructure.  An SSO solution that spans Jira, Confluence, Jive and Google Apps would be highly desirable for us.

It appears Google Apps requires a SAML implementation, and I know the Crowd folks object to this, but perhaps a Google-oriented lighter-weight implementation is possible?

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition  
Some companies may use different formats of some properties that would need to be changed, for example, date formats or mail encoding settings.

h3. Suggested Solution  
Provide an alternative to edit and change those settings.

h3. Why this is important   
Those changes reflect more accurately the information of the companies.
fields.summary: Allow editing of Crowd application properties

fields.description:
It should be possible to store the organization and the organizational unit of a principal in the internal (integrated) Crowd repository. The administrative console needs to allow to enter and edit these attributes.

Both, the organization and the organizational unit should be part of a controlled vocabulary that can be maintained within Crowd itself. This way, it can be avoided that the same organization is spelled differently for different principals.

I should note that for us already a single level (i.e. only the organization) would be a big improvement.

fields.description:
We need to import the password hashes from Confluence and JIRA into Crowd and then have a given directory use thee hashing algorithm used by JIRA and Confluence when authentication calls are made.

This means using an internal directory when importing users if they want to use this feature, since we need to control the authentication against the user repository.
fields.summary: Improve the importing of users from Confluence and JIRA so these users do not need to reset their passwords

fields.description:
Being able to choose whether to export the domain property will allow users to more easily migrate data from one instance of Crowd to another.

I would either suggest allowing them to set a value for the export, or simply not exporting the value.
fields.summary: The export function of Crowd needs to have a flag to say don't export domain.

fields.description:
The addGroup functionality in Crowd does not currently correctly implement an approach to add a user to ApacheDS.

The issue here is that according the [RFC-2256|http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2256.txt] the *groupOfUniqueNames* Object Class requires that the *uniquemember* field cannot be left blank (ie it is a required field).

Currently our code is trying to get around this by adding a blank string into this field, but ApacheDS even with this approach does not allow this.

Currently I do not have a solution beyond providing some kind of user picker on the add group page, so a person can choose a member to add to this group. However, we still need to take into account adding groups via our SOAP interface and also via the importers.
fields.summary: ApacheDS crowd integration does not currently support the adding of groups
